greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of integer partitions of 2*n having exactly 2*n submultisets.
comment: If n is odd, there are no integer partitions of n with exactly n submultisets, so this sequence gives only the even-indexed terms.
The number of submultisets of an integer partition is the product of its multiplicities, each plus one.
The Heinz numbers of these partitions are given by A325793.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..700 (first 101 terms from Andrew Howroyd)
formula: a(p) = 1 for prime p. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Aug 16 2019
example: The a(1) = 1 through a(8) = 21 partitions (A = 10, B = 11):
maple: b:= proc(n, i, p) option remember; `if`(n=0 or i=1,
mathematica: Function[w, b[w, Min[w, i - 1], r]][n - i*j], 0], {j, 0, n/i}]];
a /@ Range[0, 60] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 12 2021, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: (PARI) a(n)={if(n<1, 0, my(v=vector(2*n+1, k, vector(2*n))); v[1][1]=1; for(k=1, 2*n, forstep(j=#v, k, -1, for(m=1, (j-1)\k, for(i=1, 2*n\(m+1), v[j][i*(m+1)] += v[j-m*k][i])))); v[#v][2*n])} \\ _Andrew Howroyd_, Aug 16 2019
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, May 25 2019
ext: Terms a(31) and beyond from _Andrew Howroyd_, Aug 16 2019
